forecast.rationale:
Known facts: Samoa declared a state of emergency for the power crisis on Mar 31, 2025, scheduled through Apr 29. The question asks whether a state of emergency is in effect on Apr 30. Thus, the status quo path is No unless authorities actively extend or replace the order. There is no additional information from the research assistant indicating an imminent extension or resolution.

Assessment: Extensions are plausible—Samoa has previously extended emergencies (e.g., COVID), and if power supply issues persist, the government has both precedent and incentive to maintain emergency powers. However, emergency powers carry political cost; if short-term measures (fuel procurement, payment arrangements) stabilized supply, leadership will likely let the order lapse as scheduled. With nine days left and no public signal (as of Apr 21) of ongoing severe outages or an intent to extend, the base case favors expiration on Apr 29.

Why not higher: We lack evidence that the crisis remains acute enough to require emergency powers past Apr 29; an extension requires an active step by the government. The currently posted end date is the day before the target date.

Why not lower: The initial situation was serious enough to warrant an emergency; extensions in Samoa are institutionally straightforward and common when problems persist. If outages continue or procurement reforms aren’t in place, a short extension into May would be unsurprising.

What would move me up: Credible reports this week of continuing widespread blackouts; official statements hinting at or scheduling an extension; publication of an extension order. What would move me down: Government statements that supply is stabilized and the emergency will lapse; a revocation or confirmation of no extension by Apr 28–29.
